intro.p: Your roommate {{stu}} is working on an online homework set for intermediate algebra. "I don't understand," {{stu}} says. "I solved this inequality correctly, but the computer isn't taking my answer. Can you help?"
The problem reads: Solve the inequality. Express your answer (a) as an inequality solved for {{var}}, (b) using interval notation, and (c) by shading a portion of a number line.

{{stu}}'s answers to parts (a) and (b) are: \boxed{\; {{var}} {{asign}} {{boundary}} \;} and \boxed{\; {{aint}} \; }. "It says 'incorrect', but it doesn't say which part is incorrect," {{stu}} tells you.

content.p: Which part of {{stu}}'s solution is incorrect: the inequality, the interval, or both? Demonstrate how you know.

outtro.p: The correct solutions here are \boxed{ {{var}} {{oppsign}} {{boundary}} } and \boxed{ {{corrint}} }.

content.p: Write out a step-by-step correct solution for parts (a) and (b), pointing out to {{stu}} the error {{pn}} likely made along the way.

Show {{stu}} how to carefully shade a portion of the real number line to communicate this correct solution. In your explanation, address both whether and why you have used either an open circle or a closed cirle at the boundary of your answer.

outtro.p: A correctly shaded number line would be shaded to the {{dir}} of {{boundary}} and use {{circle}}.
